Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Story: My phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Miss you!” I glance at it, guilt prickling at the back of my mind. I haven’t called home in days, just sent a quick “I’m fine” text yesterday. I know how much it means to my parents to hear from me, especially on weekends. But right now, I’m sitting across from Alex at our favorite café, trying to memorize every detail of his face. He leaves for London tomorrow, and I promised we’d spend every moment together before he goes. He reaches for my hand, smiling softly, and I feel the weight of his expectation—be present, make this time count. My phone vibrates again. I want to call Mom, to reassure her, but I can’t pull myself away from Alex, not now. The pressure builds inside me, torn between being the attentive daughter my parents hope for and the loving girlfriend Alex needs. I stare at my phone, heart pounding, caught between two worlds, unsure which one to answer first.
